images.caption: Figure 2:Fine-tuning capability.While FLUX succeeds in learning objects (a), it struggles to capture styles (b). We enable FLUX to learn styles (c). References are shown in the red insert box.

The style prompts are â€˜minimalist flat round logoâ€™, â€˜stickerâ€™, â€˜detailed pen and ink drawingâ€™, and â€˜abstract rainbow colored flowing smoke waveâ€™. Styles emerge in the initial 10% of denoising steps; therefore, (c) and (d) fail to capture target styles. Here, we use FLUX, with the guidance scale 7 across the whole denoising process.
Figure 4:Probability distribution of Log-SNR.Colored region indicatesstyle-emergingnoise levels discussed inSec.3.1.

Figure 7:Qualitative comparison.All samples are generated with the same seed. Please zoom in.
Figure 8:Multi-panel and typography.First row demonstrates generating multiple coherent images as asingle image. Second row shows customized typography with a unique style.

Figure S1:Additional samples.Each row shows images generated with the same random seed at a resolution of 1216Ã—832, using the prompts â€œa cute city made of sushi in {style prompt} styleâ€ and â€œmischievous ferret with a playful grin squeezes itself into a large glass jar, in {style prompt} styleâ€.

Figure S2:Typography.The first column shows reference images. The second and third columns display samples generated at a resolution of 832Ã—1216, and the fourth column presents samples at 704Ã—1408 resolution. The prompts used are â€œthe words that says â€˜{letters}â€™ are written in English, in {style prompt} styleâ€, where â€˜{letters}â€™ represents the words synthesized in the samples.

Figure S3:Additional qualitative comparison.Our Style-friendly approach successfully captures complex multi-panel styles, generating images that closely resemble the reference. The prompts used are â€œA fluffy baby sloth with a knitted hat trying to figure out a laptop, close up in {style prompt} styleâ€, â€œA banana in {style prompt} styleâ€, â€œA Christmas tree in {style prompt} styleâ€, and â€œA bench in {style prompt} styleâ€.
Figure S4:Additional qualitative comparison.Our method effectively captures the multi-panel style, whereas zero-shot methods generate images with different structures or introduce artifacts.

Figure S5:VaryingÎ¼ğœ‡\muitalic_Î¼on object references.The object names are written at the top of the reference images. SettingÎ¼=0ğœ‡0\mu=0italic_Î¼ = 0(high log-SNR value) leads to failures in color binding and structure when fine-tuning on object references, whereas using the SD3 sampler allows FLUX to fine-tune object references effectively. This unveils why recent diffusion models perform well on object fine-tuning, as their noise level distributions are adjusted toward object-centric generation.
Figure S6:Comparison of fine-tuning the SD3.5-8B.The results with SD3.5-8B are consistent with the qualitative comparison based on FLUX-dev presented inFig.7.

Figure S8:Prompt switching during generation.The generated images still reflect the intended styles even without style descriptions in most of the denoising process, indicating that stylistic features emerge mainly at the early denoising steps.

Figure S10:Style prompts used for experiments.

Figure S13:Effect of Style Prompt Design.The first row shows images generated using style prompts from the StyleDrop paper[51]during both fine-tuning and generation. The second row shows images generated using a different style prompt during both fine-tuning and generation. Each column is generated using the same random seed. This demonstrates how varying the style prompt can lead to different stylistic elements being emphasized in the generated images.
